job_title: Limited Term Assistant Professor, History in Kennesaw, GA
pros: As with all part-time and visiting positions, there is very little oversight. The exception is online courses, which must be reviewed by the Digital Learning Innovations office. Everyone in the College of Humanities and Social Sciences has been kind, but they are also the standard set of awkward academics. You can enter and exit the job without meeting anyone if you really wanted. If you understand how to build a gen ed course in the humanities that requires almost no grading, then this is a wonderful position to take as you find your way outside academia.
cons: It is a temporary job with no possibility of renewal by state law. The teaching load is 5/5, but it will likely all be the same course.

review_title: Cowardly; no commitment to educational mission
pros: * pretty campus, easy parking, nice offices * depending on College and department there are options for remote work/online teaching so not required to be on campus every day * students are generally nice, diverse student body * enrollment is growing, so less risk of "cliff" than other institutions * efficient IRB * great Center for Teaching and Learning and amazing instructional designers in office of Digital Learning Innovations
cons: * ONLY CARES ABOUT RETENTION AND GRADUATION RATES; the only metric they care about to determine teaching effectiveness is DFW rate, but will not be courageous enough to actually put that in handbook or evaluation guidelines; absolutely no support to hold students to academic standards (even with proof of significant student supports, scaffolding, evidence based pedagogy); been told that the only way to succeed as a faculty member here is to have at least 80% of class receive A,B, or C, regardless of level of class, difficulty of content, student preparedness entering course, or provision of student supports (and regardless of research/publication output), many students are academically unprepared for college * administrative turnover is outrageous, priorities and initiatives change quickly and seemingly on a whim, every new President/Provost/Dean/Department Chair demands faculty do something different, therefore, senior faculty have given up doing anything since it will just change again next year * academic administration at the department and College levels have ZERO leadership or management training, secretive, cowardly, unwilling to stand up for their employees; no consequences when chairs evaluate faculty on criteria that are not actually written anywhere, no true shared governance, policies and procedures give disproportionate weight to department chairs and other admin * low pay, salary compression *increasing expectations in all categories without additional resources (told to publish and disseminate more, but do not provide enough travel money to cover a single conference or pay open access publishing charges; told to do academic advising which is not in contracted workload; told to do more to promote student success and prepare students for careers, but will not approve field trips or course work outside of the classroom or provide funding to take students to events) *USG trying to cripple higher ed similar to Florida

pros: The benefits are great as per USG.
cons: There are absolutely NO salary raises even though there is a mandatory performance evaluation each year! There are never any merit increases. You can work in the same position for five years and not be moved to a next level advising title/salary; you will always be a Level 1 even if you have over 5 year's experience. The academic advising salary at KSU does not afford a person the ability to survive. Though USG gave a $5k increase to everyone as a market rate increase, an adult especially a single parent/salary cannot truly survive on $45k/year considering the cost of living in Georgia. Rent is extremely high and truly not affordable with this salary. Working here will have an employee shopping at Goodwill, Salvation Army, Must Ministries, and getting food from pantries because the salary does not afford comfortable living. In other words, this is a great job if you are satisfied with living 'almost' paycheck to paycheck! This job will place you in the bracket of 'The Working Poor!'

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Marietta, GA
pros: You don't have to pay your tuition and you get slightly more than $1,000 every month as living expenses. Also, it's part-time, so you only work 20 hours in the lab.
cons: Depends on who you work for, but never seen any professors allow you to work 20 hours only a week. Most labs before covid-19 used to require students to stay between 9-5 every day, so it's way below minimum wage in that case. Many professors are toxic. Actually, academia is toxic, not just Kennesaw. My advisor didn't like me even if I spent 50-60 hours a week on research, and the environment heavily depends on the professors' national origin. Professors tend to hire at least 50-60% of their students from their country. They speak their languages all day in the lab. Some professors are incompetent and cannot afford your tuition, so you are likely to be fired after a semester or two.

pros: Some good colleagues trying their best
cons: Hands down the worst library administration I’ve ever worked for. They’re openly antagonistic to faculty and staff and have no long-term plan for growing the library into one that can serve an R2 institution. I was misled during the interview process about the job I would be doing, what campus I would be doing it at, and why there was so much turnover (hint: it’s not just people retiring). My key card couldn’t access my office (or any other necessary space) for over a month – this slowness regarding literally everything seems to be the rule, not an exception. I was told on several occasions “that’s just the way we do things here” and yeah, weird flex. If you’re a librarian, you get one day of telework a week (but we weren’t allowed to call it teleworking because the new Chancellor didn’t like it – office hours instead) even if your job can be done fully remotely. The library did not close during the pandemic and many staff (and almost every student) no longer wear masks. The pay is lowest in the area and, though Cobb Co. might be considered “Metro Atlanta,” it feels like a different planet. Avoid if you can!

job_title: Programming Lab Student Assistant in Marietta, GA
pros:
I really learned a lot teaching material to other students and answering questions during programming lab. I also had to learn a lot from being the knowledge source during one-on-one tutoring sessions. It was interesting to see what analogies and phrasing clicked for different people. It kept me on my feet, and I really needed to learn about the language to answer some of the more complicated questions.

It was also really convenient to have a job on-campus, and hours were flexible if I did not wait to register for tutoring lab times. My manager made sure we each had several hours of tutoring time scheduled for each lab we helped with, and she helped us resolve schedule conflicts with other lab assistants when necessary.
cons: I felt bad for the professors and students. KSU policy is pushing the CCSE department to pack programming labs to the brim, and many students need a little more patient explanation and guidance than can be offered by one professor and two assistants in a lab with 40 people. I tried my best to give people the tools to understand what was going on or at least how they could find help on their own (google the error messages), but having one more assistant would have made a big improvement.

pros: Great benefits, second to none in terms of healthcare options and retirement plans with incredible matches.  A lot of learning opportunities that working in the private sector don't offer or have access to. Working in higher education and at a large university offers a unique working environment unlike any other place as it is like working for a self-contained municipality, so it provides true growth experience outside of the traditional "rat race". I was exposed to so many new things that have been fulfilling personally as well that I never would have gotten to experience on the "outside".
cons: Current culture change and shock due to new controversial president. Staff (as opposed to faculty) salaries pale by comparison to the private sector, but that is mostly because of it being a state institution.  The benefits help offset the pay inequity.  Pay inequity is also prevalent across the board despite set, published pay bands.  Not a lot of upward mobility in most positions. You have to love what you are doing to work there.

pros: Positive environment and team collaboration
cons: Few people higher up make big controversial decisions

pros: I have an extremely flexible schedule that allows me to live a balanced life. I can telecommute and work on my degree that is paid as a benefit of full-time employment. There is a pleasant environment and many opportunities to grow and learn.
cons: No one has gotten any raises at KSU in 5 years. They charge a great deal for parking and that amount is going up. There is little movement or promotion within your department. HR has too much control over employment issues. Only those who play the politics get ahead. No good deed results in promotion.

review_title: Good place to work, but there's no money in it for staff no matter how hard one works
pros: Dedicated and competent coworkers, for the most part; great campus atmosphere. Good benefits.  Tuition reimbursement for those who qualify.  Many fun activities on campus.
cons: Hard work, or competence, is not rewarded anywhere near adequately.  Every year, it's the same old thing from the campus president: "We have to do more with less."  Way too many levels of administration, which suck up much of the cash available for raises.  Have to get a Master's Degree for any type of promotion in my department, which is ridiculous.  ENTIRELY too many layers of supervision/management, most of which are superfluous at best.

pros:
-Work in education
-Make a difference in someone's life with your work
-Work on a beautiful campus
cons:
-Needless and uninformed changes from upper management which makes doing your job much more difficult

-Low support from upper management

-Inability to use your expertise without being overridden by unqualified superiors/stakeholders 

-Most of the above issues stem from a chronic lack of communication and open channels

-Culture and work/life balance can also be an issue in some areas

These issues and more have led to massive amounts of employee departures over the last year. Leadership seems to have little interest in rectifying the issues and people continue to leave.

review_title: Adult acute/urgent/chronic medical  & injury, immunization/travel clinic, college level sport physicals, women's health
pros: Adequate on site training time, good life work balance, provides a good service for the adolescent/adult population. Staff very kind, work together well, wanted to be proactive, improve their skills and knowledge eager to learn, kind and loving to the patient population
cons:
Untrained middle management; Inadequate, unclear or difficult policies for medical actions as relates to uncommon situations
Middle Managers had a tendency to cause discourse among the working staff, discouraged an environment of cooperation
Very Difficult to getting approval for time or compensation for CEU's. 
Inadequate space for efficiency in patient care

review_title: Grants Assistant Pay with Grant Manager Demands
pros:
-Generally friendly office culture
-Outstanding outgoing VP and incoming VP, supportive/knowledgeable assistant director, and lively and extremely helpful associate VP
-Tuition assistance if you can survive 6 months
cons:
-Unorganized Executive Director/supervisor
-Not provided with a living wage, especially given the unmanageable workload and being asked to train your new managers. By the time I submitted my resignation, my workload consisted of supporting 88 grants (and counting!) 
-Lack of training for new staff (**this has recently improved for the newer team members**) 
-No real processes or technical aids in place to manage workload and requests from professors/PI's
-High turnover with no seasoned staff on your immediate team to help guide you through the university's endless rules and regulations
- Lots of promises around process improvement from ED with little to no execution

pros: Excellent place to work.  Very good benefits.  Not perfect, but still very good.  Great retirement plans.  Excellent time off.  Many many caring people.  Every department is a little different.  Working in HR I got to see some of the problems in various departments, but as a whole the university is excellent.  Highly recommend.
cons: Maybe that the pay is a little low, but it's a trade off.  What you give up in pay you more than gain in benefits, time off, and the opportunity for job growth.  Every job/career has cons.  KSU is as good as it gets.

pros: The consolidation is bringing opportunities to many people. More options are available for jobs that were limited before the consolidation. People are starting to branch out and get promotions in other areas of the university.
cons: The morale is low between departments. There is a level of unsure mentality  moving  forward in this merger. Many departments are being consolidated to one department. There is not a level playing field available at this time.

review_title: University that cares about its employees
pros: I love the work culture here. They throw in perks when they can, are flexible about time and have a range of benefits (like a rideshare program, employee fitness center, retirement plan, tuition assistance program, etc.).
cons: I've heard the salaries aren't as high as they should be, but being new to higher ed, I can't speak to that. Parking is an extra cost ($23 for standard). I'm still new here so perhaps more cons will come out later?

cons: Low pay, hard to get full time positions and  hardly any advancement opportunities. Limited on how many course you can teach per semester by USG. Only 3 courses at any 1 institution in the USG in the same semester which puts a cap on your earnings so they don't have to provide you benefits.

review_title: Employed at KSU for over 8 years, still in the same dead-end job.

Everyone and all the departments are very selfish and do not work well together. University is growing too fast and there is no support for the employees or the students.

pros: Flexible work hours, though that depends on your department

Directors and AVP's bark out orders and changes not even know what you do in your role or what you need to be successful in your job. KSU is a money hungry school who doesn't care about the staff or the students.

pros: The discount on education benefits by far have to be the best pro.  If you are a lifetime learner this is an opportunity to gain more knowledge without having to pay full tuition.
cons: I don't have any cons to share regarding the university.  I has great benefits, it is in a great location away from the hubub of Metro Atlanta but yet close enough to get to the action.  It is also close to the Georgia foothills and calmer life.

pros: The student assistants are incredible.  Most of my coworkers were great.

pros: Great starter or retirement job. The hours were great as I did 4 10s. Benefits were awesome. You get a lot of perks in the Kennesaw area.

review_title: The department I worked in was really great.
job_title: Student Assistant in Fort Worth, TX

It was a friendly work environment  in an enjoyable atmosphere.

Communication in my department about recent news was lacking at times. 
Managers could be really hard to get a hold of sometimes.

pros: Faculty and programs excellent. Exciting developments in research and innovation. Strong commitment to student learning. Increasingly competitive with UGA, GA State, and even GA Tech (after merging with Southern Poly). A comfortable place for a diverse and inclusive community. cons: Student aptitude and commitment to scholarship a mixed bag. Some students still think they are in high school and want to be told what to do at every step - and they expect to get As for doing the minimum required (I remember when that was called a C). Others demonstrate outstanding ability, creativity, and performance.

review_title: Good start out job for people wanting to get their foot in the door with higher education

review_title: Part Time Faculty for Bagwell College of Education
pros: You get to help future teachers. You learn about the different school systems and what is going on in the classrooms in different parts of Georgia. The faculty members are helpful despite their busy schedule.
cons: There is a lot of last minute hiring, change of schedule and empty promises. Part time faculty are not prepared with materials for their classroom in advance. Part time faculty have to rely on previous instructors or faculty members to teach courses. This ultimately leads to students dissatisfaction of the course.

review_title: Full Time Student with Part Time Job
pros: Worked here while I was a full-time student at KSU. Great managers, who can accommodate your hours for your schoolwork. Fully understand that school comes first, and will not over work you. Best paying job on campus for students, with nice perks of 10% of textbooks, and 20% off of all apparel and merchandise. Even though you are a student, the floor managers give you different jobs, so there is availability for growth.
cons: There are no downsides to working here. It can get hectic during the beginning and end of the semester, but don't stress.

review_title: Look elsewhere or use as a stepping stone!
pros:
1. TAP will pay for going back to school
2. Close to home(for me)
cons:
1. No longer offering working remotely (1 day/week)
2. About $15k-$25k below average pay from other places,including other USG  institutions.
3. Utilizing older technology,Oracle PL/SQL, to build apps.
4. High expectations without compensating the developer for it.
5. Constantly talking about making changes for the better and never going through with it.
6. We are currently being micromanaged on all of our projects/tasks(down to the minutes we work and on what).
7. Will paint with a broad brush on what the developer's job entails so they can ask senior developer work from a lower level developer.
8. Very bad office politics you must navigate through.

review_title: Review For WellStar School Of Nursing
pros: Some branches of Kennesaw are not communicating so it is hard to get some things done, because not everyone is in the same page.
cons: Great place to work, great management and people to work with.

review_title: Great option for students seeking professional development, networking, & supplemental income while in school
pros:
- Most of the computer science and software 
engineering professors are knowledgeable and a pleasure to work with as their teaching assistant
- You get to tutor hundreds of students one-on-one or in small groups outside of class hours in the tutoring lab with other teaching assistants.  This gives a great sense of personal fulfillment/meaning in your work in addition to enhancing/expanding your conceptual understanding, communication, and technical skills.
- For those that put care and effort into the job, the job immerses you into social and academic contexts relevant to your major and sharpens your academic focus/interest/success.
The job also tends to instill a proactive willingness-to-help/pedagogical state of mind -- a trait that often translates into being more of a team player and increasing your appeal & value in the workplace.
cons: - Occasionally you could be assigned to a bad apple professor. (Especially so is the case with online courses where sometimes professors go incognito &/or neglect their course/students/teaching assistants/communication.  E.g. a professor whose online course, 'Programming Principles I,' I TA'd for barely communicated with me or his students, and he copy & pasted another professor's syllabus for his course and didn't even stick to the course deliverables schedule/exam schedule that he provided.  For one of his exams, that particular professor failed to communicate with his TA's and his students that he had decided to postpone the exam two weeks.  He didn't respond to our emails or clarify the situation until several days after the original exam date had passed.  Meanwhile, his students had studied and made arrangements in their schedules anticipating to take the exam during the originally-scheduled period/date and had been anxiously checking the online course page for the exam to unlock or for news from the professor explaining otherwise.   After that incident, I notified my manager who then notified the department dean who then talked to the professor and rectified the situation for the most part.  Years later I checked and saw that professor was still teaching courses, some still online, so I can only hope that his tenure didn't let him go unscathed/unchanged.)

job_title: Head Lab Assistant in Kennesaw, GA

Each job at KSU is different so this particular position refers to the Head Lab Assistant position in the music department. From other workers at KSU they all love their jobs.
cons: Minimum wage. For a school job that allows you to work on homework while being payed there really aren't many cons.

pros: KSU offers a very good work/life balance with flexible work schedules for some positions and nice perks like extra vacation time and multiple holidays off.  Everyone that I worked with is quite professional.

It can be difficult to get promotional opportunities as those that are making a reasonable income usually plan on retiring at KSU.
